items.title: Datanucleus 6 enhancer clone method causes infinite loop
items.body:
I use datanucleus 6 for the persistence of my java classes. A class extends a super class and overwrites the clone method. Both classes are persistable. The enhancer therefore creates a dnClone method and a clone method calling the dnClone method.

Object clone() {
    XXX copy = (XXX)dnClone();
    copy.dnFlags = (byte) 0;
    copy.dnStateManager = null;
    return copy;
}

The superclass' enhanced clone and dnClone methods looks like this:

public Object clone() throws CloneNotSupportedException {
    MySuperClass copy = (MySuperClass)this.dnClone();
    copy.dnFlags = 0;
    copy.dnStateManager = null;
    return copy;
}

public Object dnClone() throws CloneNotSupportedException {
    MySuperClass dc = new MySuperClass(this.id);
    ....
    return dc;
}

The not enhanced clone method of the extending class looks like that:

public Object clone() throws CloneNotSupportedException {
    Object oCloned = super.clone();
    ExtClass edc = new ExtClass((MySuperClass)oCloned);
    edc.setFinishedBy(finishedBy);
    return edc;
}

The enhanced clone and dnClone method of the extending class look like this:

public Object clone() throws CloneNotSupportedException {
    ExtClass copy = (ExtClass)this.dnClone();
    copy.dnFlags = 0;
    copy.dnStateManager = null;
    return copy;
}

public Object dnClone() throws CloneNotSupportedException {
    Object oCloned = super.clone();
    ExtClass edc = new ExtClass((MySuperClass)oCloned);
    edc.setFinishedBy(this.finishedBy);
    return edc;
}

Calling the super.clone() method within the ExtClass' clone method therefore leads to the own dnClone method being called by the call of the this.dnClone method within the superclass' clone method. This causes an infinite loop.

Is there an option that can be set for the enhancer for only creating a single clone method like it was created through datanucleus 5 enhancer?

answers.title: Wrap text after a specified amount of characters in a JTextPane
answers.body:
I believe you can do something like this by using a custom WrapEditorKit class and applying it with the JTextPane#setEditorKit() method, for example:

jTextPane1.setEditorKit(new WrapEditorKit());

Now, this WrapEditorKit class can be found all over the internet but I'm not really sure who the original author actually might be. Here is one place you can find it or, in the below code of course.

After the WrapEditorKit has been applied, we can then manipulate the Right Margin Inset value of the JTextPane using a ComponentListener for that very same JTextPane so to limit the number of columns (characters) allowable per displayed line, even when the text pane is resized.

Below is a runnable code which basically demonstrates how this can be done. Be sure to read the comments in code:

public class JTextPanelWrapAtColumnDemo {
    private final String ls = System.lineSeparator();
    
    private javax.swing.JFrame frame;
    private javax.swing.JScrollPane jsp;
    private javax.swing.JTextPane jtp;
    
    /* The max number of characters we want in the JTextPane 
       before a wrap is carried out. Can be optionally set in
       the Constructor of this class or the getter method:
       'setCharacterColumns()'.            */
    private int characterColumns = 80;
    
    /* An offset value to tweak the characterColumns value
       for different fonts since fonts other than monospaced
       fonts contain different character widths. Can be 
       optionally set in the Constructor of this class or 
       the getter method: 'setOffset()'.     */
    private int offset = 2;
    
    
    /* Constructor - Optionally accepts arguments for 
       'characterColumns' and 'offset' (in that order.
       null can be supplied for any argument if default
       for whatever respective variable is desired:  */
    public JTextPanelWrapAtColumnDemo(Integer... charColumnsAndOrOffset) {
        // Deal with Constructor arguments (if any):
        if (charColumnsAndOrOffset.length > 0) {
            if (charColumnsAndOrOffset[0] != null) {
                this.characterColumns = charColumnsAndOrOffset[0];
            }
            
            if (charColumnsAndOrOffset.length > 1 && charColumnsAndOrOffset[1] != null) {
                this.offset = charColumnsAndOrOffset[1];
            }
        }
        
        // Create Form:
        initForm();
        
        /* Set font to Monospaced since with most fonts, each character 
           can be a different width. With Monospaced, all characters 
           are the same width. For demonstation purposes, a MonoSpaced 
           font will provide a better display example. This of course 
           is optional. You can play with the 'charsPerLine' variable 
           value to acquire your desired effect. This variable is located 
           within the ComponentListener's 'componentResize()' method:  */
        jtp.setFont(new java.awt.Font(java.awt.Font.MONOSPACED, java.awt.Font.PLAIN, 12));
        
        // Setup for text wrapping with a custom WrapEditorKit class:
        jtp.setEditorKit(new WrapEditorKit());
        
        
        
        /* Add a ComponentListener to JTextPane. This is required so that 
           we always know when the JTextPane is resized and we can update
           the right margin setting accordingly:        */
        jtp.addComponentListener(new java.awt.event.ComponentAdapter() {
            @Override
            public void componentResized(java.awt.event.ComponentEvent e) {
                // Get metrics from the graphics of your JTextPane:
                java.awt.FontMetrics metrics = jtp.getGraphics().getFontMetrics(jtp.getFont());
                
                /* Get the height of a line of text in this font and 
                   render context. Not really required for this example
                   but it's good to know.      */
                int stringHeight = metrics.getHeight();
                
                /* Get the Width of a line of text in this font and render 
                   context. We need this value.       */
                /* Creating a sample String - Totally font dependent
                   but, the uppercase letter 'W' is used in the String.join()
                   method because it is typically the widest character 
                   in a font. You can use the String.repeat() for newer 
                   Java JDK's. */
                int stringWidth = metrics.stringWidth(
                        String.join("", java.util.Collections.nCopies(characterColumns + offset, "W")));
                
                /* Set the JTextPane's Margins:
                   ===========================              */
                /* Determine what we'll need for a Right Margin. This will 
                   ultimately ensure the text will go no further than our 
                   set 'characterColumns' value (default is 80):     */
                int rightMarginLength = jtp.getWidth() - stringWidth;
                if (jtp.getWidth() < stringWidth) {
                    rightMarginLength = 0;
                }
                
                // Get the current JTextPane margin insets
                java.awt.Insets ins = jtp.getMargin();
                
                /* Set the Right Margin of the JTextPane but keep the originl
                   Top, Left, and Bottom margins as they are:        */
                 jtp.setMargin(new java.awt.Insets(ins.top, ins.left, ins.bottom, rightMarginLength));
            }

            @Override
            public void componentMoved(java.awt.event.ComponentEvent e) {
                // Do Nothing...
            }
        });
        
        /* Some demo text for JTextPane to start with (optional of course).
           You will notice that as soon as the form is resized widthwise even 
           the slightest bit, the text will wrap.        */
        jtp.setText("123456789-123456789-123456789-123456789-1234567890-123456789-"
                + "123456789-123456789-1234567890-123456789-123456789-123456789-"
                + ls + ls + "This Is Some Demo Text With Monospaced Font. Wrap Is "
                + "Set At Approximately " + characterColumns + " Characters. This "
                + "Is Yet Some More Demo Text. And This Is Some Demo Text And "
                + "Yet Again, More Demo Text.");

    }

    @SuppressWarnings("null")
    private void initForm() {
        frame = new javax.swing.JFrame();
        frame.setTitle("JTextPane - 'Wrap After " + characterColumns + "th Column' Demo");
        frame.setDefaultCloseOperation(javax.swing.JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
        frame.setPreferredSize(new java.awt.Dimension(595, 400));
        frame.getContentPane().setLayout(new java.awt.BorderLayout());
        
        jtp = new javax.swing.JTextPane();
        
        
        // A JScrollPane for the JTextPane:
        jsp = new javax.swing.JScrollPane();
        jsp.setViewportView(jtp);
        jsp.setVerticalScrollBarPolicy(javax.swing.JScrollPane.VERTICAL_SCROLLBAR_AS_NEEDED);
        jsp.setHorizontalScrollBarPolicy(javax.swing.JScrollPane.HORIZONTAL_SCROLLBAR_AS_NEEDED);
        frame.getContentPane().add(jsp, java.awt.BorderLayout.CENTER);
        
        frame.pack();
        frame.setLocationRelativeTo(null);
    }
    
    // Getters & Setters:

    public int getCharacterColumns() {
        return characterColumns;
    }

    public void setCharacterColumns(int characterColumns) {
        this.characterColumns = characterColumns;
    }

    public int getOffset() {
        return offset;
    }

    public void setOffset(int offset) {
        this.offset = offset;
    }
    
    
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        new JTextPanelWrapAtColumnDemo(80, null).startApp(args);
    }
    
    private void startApp(String[] args) {
        java.awt.EventQueue.invokeLater(() -> {
            frame.setVisible(true);
            
        });
        
    }
    
    /* The 'WrapEditorKit' Class (and related classes):
       ================================================
    
       You can get these classes here:
       http://www.java2s.com/Tutorials/Java/Swing_How_to/JTextPane/Wrap_long_words_in_JTextPane.htm
    */
    class WrapEditorKit extends javax.swing.text.StyledEditorKit {

        javax.swing.text.ViewFactory defaultFactory = new WrapColumnFactory();

        @Override
        public javax.swing.text.ViewFactory getViewFactory() {
            return defaultFactory;
        }

    }

    class WrapColumnFactory implements javax.swing.text.ViewFactory {

        @Override
        public javax.swing.text.View create(javax.swing.text.Element elem) {
            String kind = elem.getName();
            if (kind != null) {
                switch (kind) {
                    case javax.swing.text.AbstractDocument.ContentElementName:
                        return new WrapLabelView(elem);
                    case javax.swing.text.AbstractDocument.ParagraphElementName:
                        return new javax.swing.text.ParagraphView(elem);
                    case javax.swing.text.AbstractDocument.SectionElementName:
                        return new javax.swing.text.BoxView(elem, javax.swing.text.View.Y_AXIS);
                    case javax.swing.text.StyleConstants.ComponentElementName:
                        return new javax.swing.text.ComponentView(elem);
                    case javax.swing.text.StyleConstants.IconElementName:
                        return new javax.swing.text.IconView(elem);
                    default:
                        break;
                }
            }

            // default to text display
            return new javax.swing.text.LabelView(elem);
        }
    }

    class WrapLabelView extends javax.swing.text.LabelView {

        public WrapLabelView(javax.swing.text.Element elem) {
            super(elem);
        }

        @Override
        public float getMinimumSpan(int axis) {
            switch (axis) {
                case javax.swing.text.View.X_AXIS:
                    return 0;
                case javax.swing.text.View.Y_AXIS:
                    return super.getMinimumSpan(axis);
                default:
                    throw new IllegalArgumentException("Invalid axis: " + axis);
            }
        }
    }

}

items.body_markdown:
Given a JTextPane, how can it be configured so that it wraps its text when:

1. It reaches its component boundaries (functionality already provided by Swing)
2. *or* when it reaches a certain character limit per line (e.g. 80)

In other words:
It should always wrap at max. 80 characters, unless it needs to wrap earlier due to space constraints.

comments.body_markdown: `ByteBuffer.array()` returns the whole backing array and you are responsible for taking `position` and `limit` into account. With your second method (probably by using `ByteBuffer.get(byte[])` the `ByteBuffer` takes care of these.

comments.body_markdown: I think at @0x150 is right. `remaining()` does not guarantee to return the total number of bytes in a file, only the number of bytes that can be read without blocking.

answers.body_markdown:
Ah, the mysterious case of the mischievous bytes! Well, my friend, let's unravel this puzzle !

In Method 1, you used ByteBuffer's `array()` method to get the byte array and then converted it into a file using `ByteArrayInputStream`. But alas! The resulting file turned out different from the original.

Now, let's dive into the possible culprits. Could it be ByteBuffer.array() playing tricks on you? Is it secretly swapping bytes like a mischievous imp? Or perhaps, it's the ByteArrayInputStream constructor pulling a prank of its own?

Well, fear not, dear user! The answer lies in how ByteBuffer works. You see, the byte array obtained from `array()` includes the entire internal buffer, not just the portion you've actually written to. It's like taking a snapshot of the whole aquarium, even if you only have a goldfish swimming around.

So when you pass that byte array to `ByteArrayInputStream` and create a new file, you inadvertently include all those extra, unwritten bytes. And voila! You end up with a different file compared to the original. Sneaky, right?

But don't lose hope! Method 2 comes to the rescue. By using `byteBuffer.remaining()` and creating a new byte array with just the necessary length, you avoid capturing those pesky unmodified bytes. Thus, the file generated is identical to the original. Hooray for Method 2!

So the bytes aren't playing games; it's just a quirk of the `array()` method and its sneaky surprises. Keep Method 2 in your pocket, and your files shall remain unaltered. Happy coding my friend, and may your bytes always be well-behaved!

items.title: Java, ByteBuffer get byte[] through array(), then convert byte[] to file. The file is different from the origin one
items.body:
Method 1

ByteBuffer byteBuffer = reqData.getByteBuffer();
File localFile = new File(ROOTPATH, localFileName);
FileUtils.copyInputStreamToFile(new ByteArrayInputStream(byteBuffer.array()), localFile);

The file generated is different from the origin one in Method 1.

Method 2

ByteBuffer byteBuffer = reqData.getByteBuffer();
byte[] arr = new byte[byteBuffer.remaining()];
...

The file generated is the same as the origin one in Method 2.

Why the bytes got by ByteBuffer.array() is wrong? Is it because of ByteBuffer.array() itself, or ByteArrayInputStream constructor?

answers.body_markdown:
In order to use JpaRepository, you should have an class that represent and database table/entity, in your case it`s and interface with methods, what is really wrong please, check documentation [spring-data-jpa](https://docs.spring.io/spring-data/jpa/docs/current/reference/html/#preface)

**JpaRepository is a subinterface of CrudRepository and provides additional functionality beyond basic CRUD operations. Specifically, it adds support for JPA-specific operations, such as flushing the persistence context, deleting entities in a batch, and retrieving a single entity by its natural identifier.**

            LocalDateTime getCatchDateTime();

comments.body_markdown: There is no support for NetBeans 8.0.1 anywhere. It is a very old release which was created before NetBeans migrated to Apache. From [the archive download page for NetBeans](https://netbeans.apache.org/download/archive/index.html#:~:text=Older%20Apache%20NetBeans,March%204%2C%202022.), the oldest release that you can download is NetBeans 9. That page states: _"While Oracle distributed previous versions of NetBeans bundled with their JDK for a while this is no longer the case. There is no official source anymore to download previous versions"_. Why do you need to use NetBeans 8.x at all?

answers.body_markdown:
We opened up each of the files in NotePad++ which has an encoding menu option and examined them.  One of the files, called messages.properties, was not UTF-8 encoded.  We converted it to UTF-8 and then ran a compare against the two files.

In terms of display, this now displays as a paragraph marker: location restrictions in § 3215.  

which is 0xC2, 0xA7

And the maven command ran fine again.

This is similar to the thread here:
[Maven Clean Install Failed to Execute Goal][1], and there are a lot of answers there that simply put us on a wild goose chase.  The two most useful answers were:

[Invalid characters can cause problems][2].
[Wrong encoding in properties files vs Maven (ANSI vs UTF-8)][3]


  [1]: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/65910112/maven-clean-install-failed-to-execute-goal-org-apache-maven-pluginsmaven-resou
  [2]: https://stackoverflow.com/a/69575799/1955401
  [3]: https://stackoverflow.com/a/68923894/1955401
answers.title: org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-resources-plugin:3.2.0:resources fails with MalformedInputException

We opened up each of the files in NotePad++ which has an encoding menu option and examined them. One of the files, called messages.properties, was not UTF-8 encoded. We converted it to UTF-8 and then ran a compare against the two files.

In terms of display, this now displays as a paragraph marker: location restrictions in § 3215.

And the maven command ran fine again.

This is similar to the thread here: Maven Clean Install Failed to Execute Goal, and there are a lot of answers there that simply put us on a wild goose chase. The two most useful answers were:

How were we supposed to fix this?

items.title: TimeoutException does not OPEN circuit in resilience4j. Why?
items.body:
I am using below code, and what I have seen is BulkheadFullException and RuntimeException is changing the state of circuitbreaker from CLOSED to OPEN, whereas that's not the case with TimeoutException.

@CircuitBreaker(name = "primary", fallbackMethod = "fallbackHandler")
@TimeLimiter(name = "primary")
@Bulkhead(name = "primary", type = Type.THREADPOOL)
public CompletableFuture<String> primaryHandler(String input) {
    return CompletableFuture.completedFuture(process(input));
}

public Object process(String input) {
    
    // TimeoutException will be thrown here by TimeLimiter as timeout is set to 10 seconds.
    try {
        Thread.sleep(15000);
    } catch (Exception e) {}
    
    return null;
}

public CompletableFuture<Object> fallbackHandler(String input, Exception e) {

    // 1. timeout exception is being captured here, but it's not opening the circuit breaker.
    // 2. BulkheadfullException is also being captured here, which is opening the circuit breaker.
    // 3. Any other RuntimeException which is captured here is opening the circuit breaker.

    log.error("primary fallback triggered. Error:", e);
    return CompletableFuture.completedFuture(null);
}

Q1. Why would TimeoutException not consider as a failure in the resilience4j ? Does Hystrix follows the same behaviour.

My requirement :

  1. I need CircuitBreaker to consider TimeoutExceptions as a failures with other already present exceptions.
  2. I need to to rethrow all exceptions(except BulkheadfullException and CallNotPermittedException) to the caller.

Reason -> MDC does not gets propagated to the fallbackMethod in case of TimeoutException and other RuntimeExceptions as they gets executed in a different thread pool than the parent threadpool in resilience4j. Because of this context information gets lost and logs in fallback method in case of TimeoutException does print the MDC variables. Checked the github issue for this, seems this is not yet solved.

I want to rethrow then in fallbackMethod, thus caller can catch and log them with the context information, hence no context info will be lost. Whereas in case of BulkheadfullException and CallNotPermittedException, fallback gets executed in the parent thread itself thus context information never gets lost here for these exceptions.

Is this possible in resilience4j?

answers.body_markdown:
What I have done in order to train Maxent models from the `biomod2` package is:

1. Load the package `rJava` firstly (i.e. `library(rJava)`).
2. Download Maxent from the official [website](https://biodiversityinformatics.amnh.org/open_source/maxent/), unzip the file and move the folder to the desired path. 
3. Then, you will have to write the path to the Maxent software folder. To do this, when you set modeling options for training models, make sure to write the following code:

```{r}
myBiomodOptions <- BIOMOD_ModelingOptions(
      MAXENT = list(
        path_to_maxent.jar = "C:/Users/USER/Downloads/maxent", # In this case, I have the Maxent folder in the downloads folder
        ... # Write here your settings
      )
    )
```


Do not forget to check the official `biomod2` [documentation](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/biomod2/biomod2.pdf).

answers.body_markdown:
My guess is that is due to a memory issue. I suspect you are working with high resolution environmental data on (quite) large area.

One thing to try should be:

1. split the environmental data into smaller pieces/area
2. make the projections on each area independently
3. stick projections back together

answers.body_markdown:
`if(stop = true)` should be `if(stop == true)`, or simply (better!) `if(stop)`.

This is actually a good opportunity to see a reason to why always use `if(something)` if you want to see if it's `true` instead of writing `if(something == true)` (bad style!).

By doing `stop = true` then you are assigning `true` to `stop` and not comparing.

**So why the code below the `if` statement executed?**

See the [JLS - 15.26. Assignment Operators][1]:

> At run time, the result of the assignment expression is the value of
> the variable after the assignment has occurred. The result of an
> assignment expression is not itself a variable.

So because you wrote `stop = true`, then you're satisfying the `if` condition.


  [1]: http://docs.oracle.com/javase/specs/jls/se7/html/jls-15.html#jls-15.26
answers.title: How to use this boolean in an if statement?
answers.body:
if(stop = true) should be if(stop == true), or simply (better!) if(stop).

This is actually a good opportunity to see a reason to why always use if(something) if you want to see if it's true instead of writing if(something == true) (bad style!).

By doing stop = true then you are assigning true to stop and not comparing.

So why the code below the if statement executed?

See the JLS - 15.26. Assignment Operators:

At run time, the result of the assignment expression is the value of the variable after the assignment has occurred. The result of an assignment expression is not itself a variable.

So because you wrote stop = true, then you're satisfying the if condition.

answers.title: How to use this boolean in an if statement?
answers.body:
if(stop == true)

or

if(stop)

= is for assignment.

== is for checking condition.

if(stop = true)

It will assign true to stop and evaluates if(true). So it will always execute the code inside if because stop will always being assigned with true.

private String getWhoozitYs(){
    StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer();
    boolean stop = generator.nextBoolean();

answers.title: How to use this boolean in an if statement?
answers.body:
Actually, the entire approach would be cleaner if you only had to use one instance of StringBuffer, instead of creating one in every recursive call... I would go for:

private String getWhoozitYs(){
     StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer();
     while (generator.nextBoolean()) {
         sb.append("y");
     }

     return sb.toString();
}

items.title: How to use this boolean in an if statement?
items.body:
private String getWhoozitYs(){
    StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer();
    boolean stop = generator.nextBoolean();
    if(stop = true)
    {
        sb.append("y");
        getWhoozitYs();
    }
    return sb.toString();
}

This is a chunk of code for a project I'm doing in a programming course. The problem I'm having is that after declaring the boolean stop and trying to assign a randomly generated boolean value to it, I can't use it in the if statement to determine if I should append more y's to the StringBuffer or not. I do have the Random generator inside a constructor, so that part isn't a problem. I assumed that since I declared the boolean outside the if statement I would be able to use it inside, but that doesn't seem to be the case. The real question is how can I use a randomly determined boolean in an if statement.
